 How compliance with each rule will be achieved.

violation.
 Specific time frames for each violation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 Repeat violations require an explanation as to why the previous corrective
action plan failed to prevent a repeat violation of the rule.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.

ALLEGATION:
It is alleged that infants or young children of staff are allowed to reside with their
parents in agency residential homes and be present with residents during
programming.
2

INVESTIGATION:
On 07/31/19 this writer initiated a special investigation into the allegations described
above. The Chief Administrator and agency staff were interviewed. Documents were
also reviewed. What follows is information obtained from the aforementioned
sources.
On 08/02/19 and 11/01/19 the Chief Administrator was interviewed and provided the
following information. The agency has a long history of providing a family
environment for residents. Each of the agency homes typically have “house
parents”, who are staff that reside in the homes for a variable number of days per
week. The house parents have their biological children and spouse residing in the
agency homes with them, however, their living quarters are separate from the living
areas occupied by residents. The Chief Administrator reported that it is the agency
philosophy that staff families residing in resident houses is a treatment model that
teaches residents healthy family relationships and interactions. The Chief
Administrator referred to model as the ‘Teaching Family Model”. The Chief
Administrator reported that house parents establish healthy and appropriate
boundaries for residents when they are interacting with their biological children. The
Chief Administrator stated that the agency has known guidelines for staff to follow
when allowing biological children to interact with residents. He stated the guidelines
and boundaries are for keeping residents and the biological children of staff safe.
The Chief Administrator reported that the biological children of staff can interact with
residents during recreation time, meals, and during other day to day activities. The
Chief Administrator acknowledged that the agency does not have a policy for
regulating and providing safety for the interaction of residents with the biological
children of staff.
At the conclusion of the interview on 11/01/19 the Chief Administrator presented a
draft version of a policy addressing prohibited interactions of staff children with
residents as well as interactions allowed under the Teaching Family Model.
On 08/02/19 Staff 1, the Lead Staff of Pugsley House, was interviewed regarding
boundaries between his daughter and residents. Staff 1 typically works with Staff 2,
his spouse, and their 18 month old daughter is also present during some of the day
to day activity in the house. Staff 1 reported that residents can give his daughter a
“high five” or push her in her little car. Staff 1 reported strict boundaries are observed
and maintained between his daughter and residents. Staff 1 reported that typically
Staff 2 watches their daughter.
On 11/01/19 Staff 2, a Direct care Staff in Pugsley House, was interviewed
regarding boundaries between her daughter and residents. Staff 2 reported that their
daughter can give “high fives” to residents or touch the hands of a resident if the
resident is comfortable with this. Staff 2 reported such things as tickling are not
allowed between her daughter and residents. Staff 2 reported that at times a
resident will pat the head of her daughter. Residents are not allowed to pick up and
3

hold her daughter. Staff 2 stated that at times residents can push her daughter in a
makeshift car, (a laundry basket) on the house carpet.
APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.4109 Program statement.
(1) An institution shall have and follow a current written
program statement which specifically addresses all of the
following:
(c) Policies and procedures pertaining to admission,
care, safety, and supervision, methods for addressing
residents' needs, implementation of treatment plans, and
discharge of residents.
ANALYSIS: The agency does not have a policy regulating the interactions of
the House Parents’ children with residents. A policy is needed to
provide for the safety of residents and the biological children of
staff.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
ALLEGATION:
It is alleged that supervision is lacking when staff are caring for their biological
children while at work and on duty.
INVESTIGATION:
During the interviews with the Chief Administrator on 08/02/19 and 11/01/19 he
provided the following information. A married couple, Staff 1 and 2, have an 18
month old child and reside part of each week in Pugsley House, a residential home
for residents. The couple, Staff 1 and 2, typically work together a 7am to 11pm shift
on the days they are scheduled to work. Typically, there is a third staff working with
them. The Chief Administrator reported that if there are 8 or more residents a third
staff is always scheduled to work the same hours with Staff 1 and 2. The Chief
Administrator reported that this is needed to maintain the required ratio as well as
allow Staff 2 to remove herself and her child from a situation where a restraint is
needed. The Chief Administrator reported that the biological daughter of Staff 1 and
2 is included in the 1:8 ratio.
The Chief Administrator reported that Staff 1 and 2 are responsible for the
supervision of their biological child while also supervising residents. The Chief
Administrator reported that if there is a need for a resident restraint Staff 2, removes
4

herself, her 18 month old, and the other residents from the situation while Staff 1 and
the third staff restrain the resident.
The Chief Administrator reported that for Barton House, a married couple do reside
in the house with residents for up to a period of four days a week. Staff 3 is a male
staff married to his spouse who is not an employee of the agency. The Chief
Administrator stated that Staff 3 and his wife have a toddler and that his wife and
toddler will at times stay overnight with Staff 3.
The Chief Administrator reported that there are no house parents who reside in
Wilcox House. The Chief Administrator reported that Staff 4, who works in Wilcox
House, resides with his family in a trailer on the agency property. The Chief
Administrator reported that the oldest child of Staff 4, age 12, does interact with the
residents of Wilcox House.
During the 08/02/19 interview with Staff 1, he reported that he and his wife, Staff 2,
typically work the same shifts. Staff 1 reported that Staff 2 will typically watch their
18 month old daughter. Staff 1 reported that a third staff is usually assigned to work
with he and Staff 2. Staff 1 reported that if a restraint needs to occur he and the third
staff will conduct the restraint while Staff 2 removes their daughter from the situation.
During the 11/01/19 interview with Staff 2 she reported the following. Staff 2 reported
that she always works with her husband, Staff 1. Staff 2 reported that she usually
works 16 hour days on Saturdays and Sundays. Staff 2 reported that there is always
a third staff working during the 16 hour shifts she and Staff 1 work. Staff 2 reported
that if the house census is low she is not scheduled to work. Staff 2 reported that her
daughter is always included in the staff to resident ratio which is 1:8. Staff 2
reported that if a restraint occurs she removes herself and her daughter from the
situation and Staff 1 and the third staff conduct the restraint.
On 08/02/19 Staff 3, a Direct Care Staff was interviewed. Staff 3 offered the
following information. He resides with his spouse and three children, ages 2, 7, and
12 years of age, in a trailer on the agency property. He typically works in Wilcox
House. Staff 3 reported that his 12 year old is allowed to interact with residents with
the appropriate supervision. Staff 3 reported that he does not allow his two youngest
children to interact with residents. Staff 3 reported that he has not had a concern
with his 12 year old interacting with residents.
A review of staff schedules for each of the agency homes was reviewed for the
month of August 2019. The staffing schedule for Pugsley House indicate three staff
are scheduled daily for the awake day time hours during the month. A review of the
staff schedules for Wilcox (1:10 ratio) and Barton (1:8 ratio) indicate that the
programs are staffed within the appropriate ratios.
5

APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.4126 Sufficiency of staff.
The licensee shall have a sufficient number of
administrative, supervisory, social service, direct care, and
other staff on duty to perform the prescribed functions
required by these administrative rules and in the agency's
program statement and to provide for the continual needs,
protection, and supervision of residents.
ANALYSIS: Each of the three houses are staffed at their respective required
ratios. Pugsley House, where Staff 1 and 2 work and have their
daughter present with them, is staffed above the 1:8 ratio as
three staff work the 16 hour day time awake hours. Staff 2 does
not work if the census is low, below 8 residents. Staff 2 removes
herself and her daughter from a restraint situation and allows
Staff 1 and a third staff to conduct the restraint.
Staffing is appropriate to provide for the safety of residents and
the biological children of staff.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION NOT ESTABLISHED
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan the recommendation is for
continuance of the regular license.
